headline.main: Cookie the Monkey: Home Is Where the Heart Is

docs.abstract: Marilyn Krimm letter urges authorities to consider well-being of monkey named Cookie when considering removal from Brooklyn family (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the many locations Japan considered for the annual summit meeting of the world's leading industrialized nations, this resort town in the country's southernmost island, Okinawa, seemed a most dubious choice. Okinawa, a backwater province plagued by a tragic past, lacked the infrastructure and know-how needed to mount an international event of such magnitude. Relations between Tokyo and the former island kingdom have never been good, and the islanders have long demanded the removal of the vast American military bases that constrict their lives.

headline.main: Sun-Drenched Okinawa Is an Uneasy Place to Meet

docs.abstract: Okinawa, Japan's choice as site of economic summit meeting, is backwater province plagued by tragic past and lacking infrastructure to handle major international gathering; Japanese and American officials fret about potential for mishap and mayhem, given Okinawans' anger at large US military presence; recent arrest of US marine accused of molesting schoolgirl heightens outrage among islanders who have vowed to disrupt summit meeting; about 27,000 people form human chain around Kadena Air Base; photo; map; Pres Clinton is first US president to visit Okinawa since it reverted back to Japan in 1972 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report the exchange between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush regarding the hypothetical case of a pregnant woman facing execution (news article, July 18). Mr. Gore, you say, ''would let the woman decide whether the execution should be delayed, allowing her the option of whether or not to give birth.'' Mr. Bush ''said he would support postponing such an execution 'because there's a second life involved.' ''
docs.abstract: Christopher N Camponovo letter comments on July 18 article on responses by Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush to hypothetical question regarding pregnant woman facing execution (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the stampede of rages, it's not as menacing as road rage or as maniacal as kiddie sports rage, and it's more down to earth than air rage. But toll rage is real. ''Oh my God, people really are nasty,'' says Fay Stewart, a five-year veteran of the tollbooth at Exit 18W on the New Jersey Turnpike. ''They blame you for everything that goes wrong. Accidents, traffic. They yell and curse and throw things at you. Sometimes they say they can't wait and open the door and put the money on the ground and leave. Or they don't pay.''

headline.main: Our Towns; Inching Along In a Slow Lane To Frustration

docs.abstract: Matthew Purdy Our Towns column on citizen movements aimed at eliminating toll booths on parkways in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have yet to meet face-to-face in a debate, but they gave voters a chance today for the first time to make a side-by-side comparison as the two sat for hourlong interviews on network television. The vice president faced aggressive questioning from Tim Russert of NBC's ''Meet the Press'' on his record and past statements, while the Texas governor was asked questions of a more political nature by Sam Donaldson and Cokie Roberts on ABC's ''This Week.''

headline.main: Programs Offer Chance to Compare Bush and Gore

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush, who have yet to meet face-to-face in presidential debate, give voters a chance to make side-by-side comparison as they sit for hourlong interviews on network television; third-party candidates Ralph Nader and Patrick J Buchanan also appeared on talk shows; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When I was a kid growing up in Chicago, I used to do anything I could to put off going to bed. One of my favorite delaying tactics was to engage my mother in a discussion about the important questions of the day, questions my friends and I had debated in the backyards of our neighborhood that afternoon -- like Who did God root for, the Cubs or the White Sox? (The correct answer was, and still is, the White Sox.) Then one night I remember asking my mother something I had been wondering for a long time. ''Mom,'' I asked, ''What am I?''
docs.abstract: Don Terry article on his life as child of white mother and black father, growing up in integrated Chicago neighborhood and trying to come to terms with his mixed heritage and complicated family that includes two older half-brothers who are white; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The proportion of low-birthweight babies, those born weighing less than 5.5 pounds, has been growing steadily since 1984, a federal report released this week says. Most of the rise can be attributed to the rapid increase in the number of multiple births, especially to older white mothers using assisted-reproduction techniques like in vitro fertilization and drugs that increase ovulation. Such techniques often produce twins, triplets or quadruplets, who are far more likely than single babies to be born prematurely, and tiny. The number of twin births rose more than 50 percent from 1980 to 1997, while the number of triplets quadrupled -- with white women older than 45 having the highest rate of multiple births.

headline.main: Report Links Fertility Aids To Small Size In Newborns

docs.abstract: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development reports that proportion of low-birthweight babies has been growing steadily since 1984 and that most of the rise can be attributed to rapid increase in the number of multiple births, especially to older white mothers using assisted-reproduction techniques like in vitro fertilization and drugs that increase ovulation; graph (M)
